TextView.android:text: Criminal Liabilities in Cyberspace
Learning Outcomes
Understand how Internet can be a threat.
Possibilities for and execution of criminal conduct
Use as a medium to commit crime
Explain various means of committing crime online
Outline key element of crime
Trace and discuss various issues pertain to cyberspace
Criminal liability
is generally made up of two elements:
(1) the guilty act or omission known as the ACTUS REUS, and
(2) the prohibited state of mind or guilty mind known as the MENS REA. The mental element generally requires the proof of an intention on the part of the person who commits the criminal act.
Most criminal offences require the coexistence of the above two elements (i.e. actus reus and mens rea) at the same time.
The concept is derived from the Latin expression:
"actus non facit reum nisi mens sit rea"
"the act will not make a person guilty unless the mind is also guilty"
A person is not guilty of murder if he caused the death of another person by accidentally knocking him down with his car.
The mens rea for the offence of murder requires an intention to kill another person or cause him very serious bodily injury, which is lacking in this example.

However, this person may have committed the offence of dangerous driving causing death because the mens rea requires in such an offence is an intention to drive the car, which is present in the example.
Whether this person is guilty of that offence depends on whether he committed the actus reus , i.e. whether he drove his car in a dangerous manner as defined in the legislation
What is Cyberspace
The notional environment in which communication over computer networks occurs. (Oxford Dictionary)
What can we do in CyberSpace?
Business and Commerce
Computer Crime/Cybercrime
Computer crime, or Cybercrime, refers to any crime that involves a computer and a network. The computer may have been used in the commission of a crime, or it may be the target.
Crimes Facilitated by Computer
Computer / computer system as a target
Crimes Facilitated by Computer
When individual/company is the main target of Cybercrime, the Internet, a computer or a computer network or device can be use as the tool or medium of committing the crime
The crime may not be new. Example:
Other complex crime in Information Age
What are Best Approach?
Regulators agree to prevent, fight and punish such crimes similarly to in real/physical life.
Fraud and Identity Theft
Cyber fraud is using Internet, or computer to convey false or fraudulent information
To offer sale to consumers goods or services that do not exits or different from advertised
To unlawfully transmit another’s money, access devices, or other valuables to another’s control.
Example: identity theft – stealing an identity (information)
Tactics Used to Commit Identity Theft
Malvertising - malicious or fraudulent content camouflaged as a run-of-the mill advertisement
Pretexting - obtaining personal information by impersonating someone
Privacy Violations / Invasions
Our current life style- Internet connected, using computer make us vulnerable to privacy invasion
Any unauthorized access to another’s computer or use of information obtained without permission could lead to criminal prosecution
Computer Privacy Violations Form
Clickstream data analysis
Man in the middle attack
VoIP - government access
Web bug
Deep Packet Inspection
Cyberstalking, Cyberharassment and Cyberbullying
Hacking into someone’s computer or mobile device or online account, or installing any trojan or tracking device is a crime under the Computer Crimes Act 1997

Sending messages threatening to harass or harm (bully) a person – depending on the content, this may amount to a criminal offence under the Communications and Multimedia Act 1998 or Section 503 of the Penal Code (criminal intimidation)
The Personal Data Protection Act 2010 only applies to commercial transactions
It does not protect our personal information being spread in social media by malicious people or stalker
Other Crime
Intellectual property crimes
Wrongful Registration of Domain Name - cybersquatting
Computer / Computer System as a Target
When the computer or computer system is the main target of Cybercrime, the computer can be considered as the tool.
Viruses, worm and Trojan horses
Denial of Service Attacks
Cybercrime Impact on Law Enforcement
Technical challenges
Legal Challenges
Operational Challenges
Technical Challenges
Rapid changes in technology
The inability of law enforcement bodies to stay current in technology
Short comings in technology affect and even impair law enforcements’ ability to find and prosecute cybercriminals
Legal Challenges
Procedural hurdles or barriers and the inability with legal system around the world to keep up with technological changes
Ever-changing business environment
Operational Challenges
Lack of equipment
Lack of training
Inadequate organizational structures
Despite of time zone, cultural and language differences operation must be done quickly
Malaysia Cyberlaw to Address The Criminal
Communications and Multimedia Act 1998
Computer Crimes Act 1997
Copyright Act (Amendment) 1997
Digital Signature Act 1997
Electronic Commerce Act 2006
Electronic Government Activities Act 2007
Payment Systems Act 2003
Personal Data Protection Act 2010
Telemedicine Act 1997
Penal Code (including Chapter on terrorism & cyberterrorism)
Communications and Multimedia Content Code
End of Chapter 4
